intro: Conchidium pusillum, commonly known as the dwarf conchidium, is a small, aquatic plant native to freshwater environments in Southeast Asia. It belongs to the family Hydrocharitaceae and is characterized by its delicate, branching stems and small, spirally arranged leaves. The plant thrives in shallow, nutrient-rich waters and is often found in slow-moving streams and ponds. Its reproductive structures are inconspicuous, with flowers that are typically submerged and pollinated by aquatic insects. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
